```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)

library(tidyverse)
library(scales)
library(RcppRoll)
library(rvest)
library(WDI)
library(janitor)
library(ggthemes)
library(zoo)

# rm(list = ls()); gc()

setwd(dirname(rstudioapi::getActiveDocumentContext()$path))

source("../../initial_setup.R")

```


```{r get raw data download, include=FALSE}

gdp_ppp <- 
  WDI(indicator = "NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD", start = 1990) |>
  # WDI(indicator = "NY.GDP.MKTP.CD") |>  
  as_tibble() |> 
  rename(gdp_ppp = 5)

gdp_ppp |> write_csv("gdp_ppp.csv")

```


```{r russia president gdp plot, include=FALSE}

russia_presidents <- 
  read_html("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_Russia") |> 
  html_elements("table") |> 
  html_table()

russia_presidents <- 
  russia_presidents[[2]] |> 
  janitor::row_to_names(row_number = 1) |> 
  janitor::clean_names() |> 
  select(president, term_of_office) |> 
  unique() |> 
  extract(
    president, into = c("president_eng", "president_rus"),
    regex = "([a-zA-Z ]+)([–∞-—è–ê-–Ø ]+).+"
  ) |> 
  extract(
    term_of_office, into = c("start", "end"),
    regex = "([a-zA-Z0-9 ]+) ‚Äì ([a-zA-Z0-9 ]+).+"
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    start = dmy(start),
    end = lead(start) - days(1),
    president_number = as.character(row_number())
  ) |> 
  pivot_longer(c(start, end), values_to = "date") |> 
  filter(!is.na(date))

sanction_date = as.Date("2014-03-26")

gdp_ppp_ceiling <- 
  gdp_ppp |> 
  filter(iso3c == "RUS") |> 
  filter(gdp_ppp == max(gdp_ppp)) |> 
  mutate(gdp_ppp = ceiling(gdp_ppp/1e12) * 1000) |> 
  pull(gdp_ppp)
  

Russia_GDP_plot_data <- 
  gdp_ppp |> 
  filter(iso3c == "RUS") |> 
  mutate(date = ym(paste(year, 12)) + months(1) - days(1)) |> 
  select(gdp_ppp, date) |> 
  bind_rows(
    tibble(date = sanction_date)
  ) |> 
  full_join(russia_presidents, join_by(date)) |> 
  arrange(date) |> 
  fill(contains("president"), .direction = "down") |> 
  mutate(
    gdp_ppp = na.approx(gdp_ppp, x = date, na.rm = FALSE),
    gdp_ppp = gdp_ppp / 1e9,
    max_min_value = ifelse(date == max(date) | date == min(date), gdp_ppp, NA),
    max_min_value = number(max_min_value, accuracy = 1, big.mark = ""),
    sanctions = ifelse(date >= sanction_date, gdp_ppp_ceiling - gdp_ppp, NA)
  ) |> 
  filter(!is.na(gdp_ppp)) |> 
  select(-name)


plot_text <- 
  russia_presidents |> 
  pivot_wider(values_from = date) |> 
  bind_rows(
    tibble(
      president_eng = "Sanctions,\neconomic war",
      president_rus = "–°–∞–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏,\n—ç–∫–æ–Ω–æ–º–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∞—è –≤–æ–π–Ω–∞",
      start = sanction_date
    )
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    end = ifelse(
      is.na(end),
      Russia_GDP_plot_data |>
        slice_max(date) |>
        pull(date),
      end
    ),
    start = as.numeric(start),
    date_middle = (start + end)/2,
    date_middle = as.Date(date_middle),
    y = ifelse(!grepl("Sanctions", president_eng), 450, 6000)
  ) |> 
  transmute(
    date = date_middle, y, 
    president_eng = ifelse(
      grepl("Medvedev", president_eng),
      str_replace(president_eng, " ", "\n"), 
      president_eng
    )
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    president_eng = case_when(
      grepl("Yeltsin", president_eng) ~ "‘≤’∏÷Ä’´’Ω ‘µ’¨÷Å’´’∂",
      grepl("Medvedev", president_eng) ~ "‘¥’¥’´’ø÷Ä’´\n’Ñ’•’§’æ’•’§÷á",  
      grepl("Putin", president_eng) ~ "’é’¨’°’§’´’¥’´÷Ä ’ä’∏÷Ç’ø’´’∂",   
      grepl("Sanctions", president_eng) ~ "’ä’°’ø’™’°’¥’´’ª’∏÷Å’∂’•÷Ä,\n’ø’∂’ø’•’Ω’°’Ø’°’∂ ’∫’°’ø’•÷Ä’°’¶’¥",  
    )
  )

plot_russia_president_gdp <- 
  Russia_GDP_plot_data |> 
  ggplot(aes(date, gdp_ppp)) +
  geom_area(
    data =  Russia_GDP_plot_data |> 
      pivot_longer(c(sanctions, gdp_ppp), values_to = "gdp_ppp") |> 
      mutate(
        president_number = ifelse(name == "sanctions", 3.5, president_number),
      ),
    mapping = aes(fill = president_number),
    alpha = 1
  ) +
  geom_text(aes(y = gdp_ppp + max(gdp_ppp) * 0.04, label = max_min_value)) +
  geom_text(
    data = plot_text,
    mapping = aes(date, y, label = president_eng, color = ifelse(y == max(y), "black", "white"))
  ) +
  geom_line(color = new_palette_colors[6], alpha = 1, linewidth = 1.5) +
  scale_x_date(
    date_breaks = "2 years", date_labels = "%Y",
    limits = c(as.Date("1990-01-01"), as.Date("2024-01-01"))
  ) +
  geom_text(
    data = tibble(x = ymd("1990-01-01"), y = 6800, label = "’å’∏÷Ç’Ω’°’Ω’ø’°’∂’® 4-÷Ä’§ ’°’¥’•’∂’°’≠’∏’∑’∏÷Ä ’ø’∂’ø’•’Ω’∏÷Ç’©’µ’∏÷Ç’∂’∂ ’ß", color = "d"),
    aes(x, y, label = label),
    hjust = 0, size = 6.5, alpha = 1,
    color = new_palette_colors[2], fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    data = tibble(x = ymd("1990-01-01"), y = 6350, label = "’å’∏÷Ç’Ω’°’ø’°’∂’´ ’Ä’Ü‘±-’∂ (’£’∂’∏’≤’∏÷Ç’©’∂’°’Ø’∏÷Ç’©’µ’°’∂ ’∫’°÷Ä’´’ø’∏’ø’∏’æ ’≥’∑’£÷Ä’ø’æ’°’Æ)\n’Ñ’¨÷Ä’§ ‘±’Ñ’Ü ’§’∏’¨’°÷Ä", color = "d"),
    aes(x, y, label = label),
    hjust = 0, size = 4, alpha = 1,
    color = new_palette_colors[6], fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  # scale_y_log10() +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 6e3, 1e3), labels = number_format()) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(new_palette_colors[c(2,6,8)], "#eeeeee", new_palette_colors[6])
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("black", "white")) +
  labs(
    x = NULL, y = NULL,
    # title = "’å’∏÷Ç’Ω’°’Ω’ø’°’∂’® 4-÷Ä’§ ’°’¥’•’∂’°’≠’∏’∑’∏÷Ä ’ø’∂’ø’•’Ω’∏÷Ç’©’µ’∏÷Ç’∂’∂ ’ß",
    # subtitle = "’å’∏÷Ç’Ω’°’ø’°’∂’´ ’Ä’Ü‘±-’∂ (’£’∂’∏’≤’∏÷Ç’©’∂’°’Ø’∏÷Ç’©’µ’°’∂ ’∫’°÷Ä’´’ø’∏’ø’∏’æ ’≥’∑’£÷Ä’ø’æ’°’Æ)\n’Ñ’¨÷Ä’§ ‘±’Ñ’Ü ’§’∏’¨’°÷Ä",
    caption = caption_f(language = "arm", source = "’Ä’°’¥’°’∑’≠’°÷Ä’∞’°’µ’´’∂ ’¢’°’∂’Ø"),
  ) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "drop",
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.y = element_line(
      colour = "gray", linewidth = 0.1,
      linetype = 1
    )
  )
```

## English Summary

### üí∂üìèüîé Beyond the Average Wage

**The Real Picture of Wages in Armenia: One Country, Two Different Economies**

The analysis of wages in Armenia reveals a stark economic divide, with Yerevan emerging as the country's economic powerhouse. Nearly 80% of the national wage fund is concentrated in the capital, attracting high-paying jobs particularly in finance and IT sectors. This concentration has led to significant wage disparities: while the top 10% of earners have seen their real wages increase by an impressive 70.6% since 2018, those in the bottom 10% have experienced a modest 14.5% growth. The median wage of 223,000 drams (before taxes) is notably lower than the average wage of 282,568 drams, highlighting the skewed income distribution.

The wage analysis also uncovers concerning trends in purchasing power and regional development. When adjusted for inflation, the real wages for lower-income groups have remained virtually stagnant, indicating that despite nominal wage increases, their purchasing power has not improved. To address this growing economic divide, the newsletter proposes a bold strategy of targeted tax incentives to stimulate development in regions outside Yerevan. This approach aims to encourage industrial activity and job creation in less developed areas, potentially expanding the tax base by incentivizing businesses operating in the shadow economy to formalize their operations.
